column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER
#Text=X

#Text=Newman continued to see his friends the Tristrams with a good deal of frequency , though if you had listened to Mrs. Tristram ’s account of the matter you would have supposed that they had been cynically repudiated for the sake of grander acquaintance .
#Text=“ We were all very well so long as we had no rivals — we were better than nothing .
#Text=But now that you have become the fashion , and have your pick every day of three invitations to dinner , we are tossed into the corner .
#Text=I am sure it is very good of you to come and see us once a month ; I wonder you do n’t send us your cards in an envelope .
#Text=When you do , pray have them with black edges ; it will be for the death of my last illusion . ”
#Text=It was in this incisive strain that Mrs. Tristram moralized over Newman ’s so-called neglect , which was in reality a most exemplary constancy .
#Text=Of course she was joking , but there was always something ironical in her jokes , as there was always something jocular in her gravity .
#Text=“ I know no better proof that I have treated you very well , ” Newman had said , “ than the fact that you make so free with my character .
#Text=Familiarity breeds contempt ; I have made myself too cheap .
#Text=If I had a little proper pride I would stay away a while , and when you asked me to dinner say I was going to the Princess Borealska ’s .

#Text=But I have not any pride where my pleasure is concerned , and to keep you in the humor to see me — if you must see me only to call me bad names — I will agree to anything you choose ; I will admit that I am the biggest snob in Paris . ”

#Text=Newman , in fact , had declined an invitation personally given by the Princess Borealska , an inquiring Polish lady to whom he had been presented , on the ground that on that particular day he always dined at Mrs. Tristram ’s ; and it was only a tenderly perverse theory of his hostess of the Avenue d’Iéna that he was faithless to his early friendships .
#Text=She needed the theory to explain a certain moral irritation by which she was often visited ; though , if this explanation was unsound , a deeper analyst than I must give the right one .
#Text=Having launched our hero upon the current which was bearing him so rapidly along , she appeared but half-pleased at its swiftness .
#Text=She had succeeded too well ; she had played her game too cleverly and she wished to mix up the cards .
#Text=Newman had told her , in due season , that her friend was “ satisfactory . ”
#Text=The epithet was not romantic , but Mrs. Tristram had no difficulty in perceiving that , in essentials , the feeling which lay beneath it was .

#Text=Indeed , the mild , expansive brevity with which it was uttered , and a certain look , at once appealing and inscrutable , that issued from Newman ’s half-closed eyes as he leaned his head against the back of his chair , seemed to her the most eloquent attestation of a mature sentiment that she had ever encountered .

#Text=Newman was , according to the French phrase , only abounding in her own sense , but his temperate raptures exerted a singular effect upon the ardor which she herself had so freely manifested a few months before .

#Text=She now seemed inclined to take a purely critical view of Madame de Cintré , and wished to have it understood that she did not in the least answer for her being a compendium of all the virtues . “ No woman was ever so good as that woman seems , ” she said .
#Text=“ Remember what Shakespeare calls Desdemona ; ‘ a supersubtle Venetian . ’ Madame de Cintré is a supersubtle Parisian .

#Text=She is a charming woman , and she has five hundred merits ; but you had better keep that in mind . ” Was Mrs. Tristram simply finding out that she was jealous of her dear friend on the other side of the Seine , and that in undertaking to provide Newman with an ideal wife she had counted too much on her own disinterestedness ?
#Text=We may be permitted to doubt it .
#Text=The inconsistent little lady of the Avenue d’Iéna had an insuperable need of changing her place , intellectually .
#Text=She had a lively imagination , and she was capable , at certain times , of imagining the direct reverse of her most cherished beliefs , with a vividness more intense than that of conviction .
#Text=She got tired of thinking aright ; but there was no serious harm in it , as she got equally tired of thinking wrong .
#Text=In the midst of her mysterious perversities she had admirable flashes of justice .
#Text=One of these occurred when Newman related to her that he had made a formal proposal to Madame de Cintré .
#Text=He repeated in a few words what he had said , and in a great many what she had answered .
#Text=Mrs. Tristram listened with extreme interest .
#Text=“ But after all , ” said Newman , “ there is nothing to congratulate me upon .
#Text=It is not a triumph . ”
#Text=“ I beg your pardon , ” said Mrs. Tristram ; “ it is a great triumph .
#Text=It is a great triumph that she did not silence you at the first word , and request you never to speak to her again . ”
#Text=“ I do n’t see that , ” observed Newman .
#Text=“ Of course you do n’t ; Heaven forbid you should ! When I told you to go on your own way and do what came into your head , I had no idea you would go over the ground so fast .
#Text=I never dreamed you would offer yourself after five or six morning-calls .
#Text=As yet , what had you done to make her like you ?
#Text=You had simply sat — not very straight — and stared at her .
#Text=But she does like you . ”
